title: Understanding Lactate Levels and Fat Oxidation
content: Discussion on lactate levels, fat oxidation, the relationship between watts and lactate, and how carbohydrates in food can affect lactate levels. Equal lactate outputs in an athlete and a metabolically unhealthy individual can mean different things and need different interpretations.

title: Zone 2 Exercise and Training
content: Specifics around Zone 2 exercise including what metrics to use to know if you’re in Zone 2, how to structure an ideal Zone 2 training program without a lactate meter with regards to duration, timing, frequency. The importance of compounding the rate of improvement that can happen with Zone 2 training.

title: VO2 Max and High Intensity Training
content: Discussion on VO2 max and high intensity training, where that fits in with overall Zone 2 training, and how exercise can have such a large impact on longevity.

title: Metformin and Mitochondrial Health
content: Discussion on Metformin and its potential impact on the mitochondria, claims that NAD can boost mitochondrial health, and the difference between healthy versus unhealthy mitochondria.

title: Long COVID and Mitochondrial Effects
content: Discussion on a study on long COVID patients, which revealed effects on the mitochondria that were reminiscent of type 2 diabetes.

title: Physiological Testing in Athletes
content: Physiological testing of athletes can reveal their capabilities, such as their ability to clear lactate and put out a great amount of power for long periods of time. Blood lactate levels at a given power output can be measured.

title: Metabolomics in Athletic Performance
content: Development of a platform for metabolomics that can look at hundreds, if not thousands of metabolites in the human body. This can be used in assessing athletic performance in cyclists and how that impacts race strategy.

title: Cyclist Performance Metrics
content: One of the most telling data points for a cyclist is lactate production (y-axis) versus watts per kilo (x-axis). A normal climbing tempo in the Tour de France is about 5 watts. Someone at that intensity might have already six millimoles (mmol) of lactate, where it would be 1 mmol at resting levels. This can predict how taxing the work is and really predicts performance. They test this with different racing simulations; this measurement is very predictive. Knowing the power output a rider can sustain for specific times and climbs tells a lot about his capabilities.

title: Impact of Performance-Enhancing Drugs
content: The best cyclists, using performance enhancing drugs, were putting out between 6.8-7.1 watts per kilo FTP. Cyclists today are not doing that. A cyclist could probably win the tour today at 6.1 watts per kilo. On the short climbs they may be at 7.2, now they’re doing 6.3 maybe. The longer climbs they’re doing 5.5, 5.8.

title: Athlete's Data Privacy
content: Team policy usually keeps this data private. But if the data is released, there will always be people who will not believe it or think the data is altered. Some teams and riders are releasing their data.

title: Advancements in Sports Technology
content: Advances in technology have made more data available to the viewer in sports. This includes the drivers speed, gear, the difference between throttle and brake pressure, and communication with race engineers. New camera angles have been introduced to show what the driver sees. In cycling, cameras installed in the front and back give a sense of the difficulty of sprinting at high speeds or descending. Power output can be seen in real time, although this is an estimation and only available for riders who wear the Velon.

title: Potential of Biosensors in Sports
content: The world of biosensors is expected to revolutionize sports by allowing the viewing of different parameters of athletes in real time. This could include seeing lactate and glucose levels in real time, which is technologically feasible and would be beneficial for all sports.

title: Importance of Strategy in Sports
content: In sports like cycling, strategy plays a crucial role. This includes understanding the course, such as knowing that the top of a climb is not the end of the stage and that there is a long descent ahead. Staying calm and maintaining a gap is an important strategy. It also involves strategic decision making, such as not following attacking cyclists if there is plenty of time to catch up.

title: Zone 2 Training and Fat Oxidation
content: In training, time spent in Zone 2 varies over the course of the year. In the winter, 70-80% of the days are spent training in Zone 2. As the season gets closer, the number of high intensity days increases. Different energy systems are alternated throughout the year to achieve certain goals. Zone 2 exercise intensity is the best at stimulating mitochondrial function and fat oxidation and lactate cleanse capacity. Lactate can be used as a fuel and is a great fuel for cells.

title: Lactate Oxidation and Energy Production
content: Lactate is oxidized in the mitochondria to produce energy. This requires MCTs (monocarboxylate transporters) to move the lactate from the cytoplasm of the cell into the mitochondria. This is stimulated with Zone 2 training.

title: Zone 2 Training and Fat Oxidation
content: Zone 2 training is characterized by a high level of fat oxidation. Fat oxidation increases in Zone 2 training. As exercise intensity increases the fatmax starts to go down sharply.

title: Measuring Fat Oxidation
content: Ways fat oxidation can be measured: Patients can be hooked up to an indirect calorimeter. They wear a mask over their nose and mouth that has the ability to measure the amount of oxygen consumed using an O2 sensor. O2 is coming in at 21% and whatever is exhaled is the difference between that. There is a similar sensor for CO2, so you know how much CO2 is produced.

title: Exercise Intensity and Oxidation
content: Oxidation of fats and carbohydrates vary depending on exercise intensity. As exercise intensity increases, one needs more oxygen. VO2 increases, and more CO2 is produced. In a lipolytic state, a more fatty oxygenation state, you still consume oxygen, but you do not produce as much CO2. In a more glycolytic state, which occurs at higher exercise intensity, you’re using more glucose for energy purposes, consuming more oxygen and producing more CO2.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Metabolic Flexibility
content: Using fat and carbohydrate utilization to calculate the mitochondrial function and metabolic flexibility. Metabolism of elite athletes compared to a recreational athlete, or someone with metabolic disease. This reflects what’s happening in the mitochondria and how the mitochondria oxidizes those fuels at different exercise intensities.

title: Determining Oxidation of Fat and Carbohydrates
content: Determining oxidation of fat and carbohydrates indicates mitochondrial function. This can be plotted to produce a metabolic map of fat oxidation and carbohydrate oxidation. In an indirect way, you can calculate the mitochondrial function and metabolic flexibility, to determine how fats and carbohydrates are utilized. This can allow you to determine training zones.

title: Correlation Between Mitochondrial Function Methodologies
content: A very high correlation exists between indirect methodology to look at mitochondrial function and the direct methodology, which is through muscle biopsy and injecting the substrate and seeing how it’s oxidized.

title: Lactate Levels and Fat Oxidation in Zone 2 Exercise
content: The change in blood lactate levels as workload increases can be used to define Zone 2 training. Resting blood lactate levels are going to be used more and more as a biomarker, like resting blood glucose levels. In patients with type 2 diabetes or profound metabolic syndrome their resting blood lactate levels are 1.5-3 mmol. Using blood lactate levels to define Zone 2 exercise in individuals with different levels of fitness is a common practice.

title: Analysis of Fat Oxidation Changes as Workload Increases
content: The second figure looks at the same groups of individuals, the same independent variable (workload in watts, x-axis), but now the dependent variable is fat oxidation (y-axis). Fat oxidation is easy to calculate via indirect calorimetry. The fitter the individual, the higher their absolute capacity for fat oxidation. A fit individual will actually increase fat oxidation to a local maxima before that oxidation begins to decline whereas most mortals begin at a maximum and decline from there.

title: Exercise Intensity and Fat Oxidation
content: In people who are not very fit, starting above 1.5 watts/kg may be too much. If you started at 0.5 watts/kg, you might see a higher fat oxidation. If you start at 2 or 1.5 watts/kg with someone who has significant metabolic dysregulation, you’re going to miss their fat max (maximum fat oxidation, fat max ox). Fat max ox is occurring earlier than when blood lactate levels reach 2 mmol. The moderately fit person hits their maximum fat oxidation at about 130 watts, but they’re hitting a lactate of 2 at 175 watts. The professional athlete is hitting maximum fat oxidation a little shy of 250 watts but they’re hitting 2 mmol of lactate closer to 300 watts.

title: Relating Maximum Fat Oxidation to Zone 2 Exercise
content: Zone 2 should be redefined as the place where maximum fat oxidation occurs. Using a blood lactate level of 2 mmol might be too much. Everything is related to the lactate kinetics and lactate oxidation in the mitochondria.

title: Lactate Levels and Metabolic Stress
content: The same blood lactate concentration in an elite athlete does not correspond to the same metabolic stress in a recreational athlete. 2 mmol lactate in elite athletes might be a higher metabolic stress than 2 mmol in a patient with metabolic syndrome. A patient with metabolic syndrome can exercise for a couple hours with a blood lactate level of 2.5 mmol. A professional athlete is going to be hurting at that lactate level. 4 mmol is the gold standard for lactate threshold.

title: Metabolism of Lactate
content: When someone has high power output, they need a lot of glycolysis to provide that energy; this will produce lactate. Lactate is the mandatory obligatory byproduct, not waste product, but byproduct of glycolysis. So the higher the glycolysis, the higher the lactate. Lactate has 2 routes it can take. 1) Lactate can go from the fast twitch muscle fibers to the slow twitch muscle fibers. This is the lactate shadow that George Brooks discovered. Lactate is oxidized in the mitochondria of those slow twitch muscle fibers. 2) Lactate can be exported to the blood. This occurs when there is poor mitochondrial function.

title: Training for Metabolic Function and Mitochondrial Performance
content: How should the moderately active individual train to maximize mitochondrial performance? Based on these data, the moderately active individual hits 2 mmol lactate at 175 watts but max fat oxidation at 125 watts. That’s a 50 watt difference. What should this person do to improve metabolic function, mitochondrial performance, fuel flexibility? Should Zone 2 be defined as 125 watts or 175 watts?

title: Correlation Between Blood Lactate Levels and Fat Oxidation
content: A correlation between blood lactate levels and fat oxidation is observed. An initial increase in fat oxidation is followed by a decline. Lactate production increases with increased power output. The crossover point in these 2 lines occurs at a high wattage in elite athletes, in moderately active people it’s closer to 180 watts, and in individuals with metabolic syndrome it’s about 125 watts. As exercise intensity increases, one needs to oxidize more carbohydrates. As exercise intensity increases beyond a certain point, fat oxidation declines sharply and disappears. High intensity exercise requires energy to be produced quickly by glycolysis (utilization of carbohydrates). Lactate is the byproduct of glucose utilization.

title: Relationship Between Blood Lactate Levels and Carbohydrate Utilization
content: There is a relationship between blood lactate levels and carbohydrate utilization as the power output of exercise increases. The correlations are quite good because lactate is the byproduct of glucose utilization. In the elite athletes, the gap is wider; they use a lot of glucose. The larger the gap between the blood lactate curve and carbohydrate oxidation curve, the more efficient the individual is in clearing lactate (oxidizing lactate). Here the lactate doesn’t show up in the blood, it stays in the muscle. This reflects the lactate shuttle (MCT transporters at work); this allows the mitochondria to use lactate as a fuel.

title: Bioenergetics of the Cell
content: The cell uses 2 main substrates for fuel: fatty acids and pyruvate, but also lactate. Normally glucose goes through glycolysis and ends up in the cytosol, outside the mitochondria, where it is oxidized to pyruvate. That pyruvate enters the mitochondria via a pyruvate carrier. In the mitochondria it’s oxidized to acetyl-CoA which enters the Krebs cycle (aka the citric acid cycle). Complete oxidation of glucose occurs via oxidative phosphorylation using the the electron transport chain. Fatty acids use a similar mechanism. Fatty acids get converted to acetyl-CoA through different mechanisms. Fatty acids are processed by CPT-1 then CPT-2; this converts them to acetyl-CoA in the mitochondria for oxidation. But every time you use glucose, you produce pyruvate. And every single time, that pyruvate is going to be reduced to lactate. When glycolysis is utilized rapidly, this will deplete NAD+ and the only way to replenish it is to reduce pyruvate to lactate. This is necessary for glycolysis to continue. But this lactate enters the mitochondria through a specific transporter (MCT1), then a specific enzyme (LDH, lactate dehydrogenase) oxidizes lactate back to pyruvate so it can enter the Krebs cycle. Lactate acts as an extra fuel, but to utilize it, these transporters must be expressed.

title: Mitochondrial Metabolite Transport
content: 3 transporters that are needed to move metabolites into the mitochondria where they can be used for the most efficient form of ATP production (they will enter the Krebs cycle and then the electron transport chain for oxidative phosphorylation). Fatty acids enter the mitochondria via CPT and are converted to Acetyl-CoA (2 carbon molecule) that can enter the Krebs cycle. There are 2 fates of glucose byproducts. 1) Traditionally we think of glucose being reduced to pyruvate (via glycolysis), pyruvate entering the mitochondria then being converted to acetyl-CoA. This follows the same fate of the fatty acid (Krebs cycle + electron transport chain = ATP). As energy demands increase, no matter how fit you are, at some point you produce more lactate and don’t have enough cellular oxygen to go down this first route. 2) If there are enough MCT1 transporters in the mitochondria, you can bring lactate into the mitochondria for oxidative phosphorylation. Lactate is converted back to pyruvate. Pyruvate becomes acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA enters the Krebs cycle, and this will continue on to the electron transport chain where the majority of ATP is produced. Oxidation of lactate will produce 32 units of ATP instead of just the 2 ATP made by glycolysis and the reduction of pyruvate to lactate.

title: MCT Transporters and Lactate Oxidation
content: Increased expression of MCT transporters allows for increased oxidation of lactate. Having more MCT1 transporters will allow for increased oxidation of lactate. There is a genetic component to this. There is also an epigenetic component. Expression can be affected by how you train, how you rest, how you eat, etc. Training is aimed at increasing the MCT1 transporters for lactate and also pyruvate. These transporters are downregulated in people who are sedentary.

title: Glucose and Lactate in Exercise
content: Fast twitch muscle fibers use glucose. During high intensity exercise (climbing, running at high intensity or swimming, etc) requires glucose. Glucose is converted to pyruvate then to keep glycolysis going, pyruvate is converted to lactate. This yields less ATP than going through the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain, but it provides ATP much faster. The ATP generated from lactate production occurs much faster than oxidation of fatty acids. Using glucose as a fuel always results in the production of pyruvate. Higher intensity exercise results in the production of more pyruvate and then more lactate. Lactate has 2 routes it can take. 1) Lactate can enter the mitochondria via MCT1. It can be taken into the cell then into the mitochondria via MCT1 where it will be converted to pyruvate → acetyl-CoA then enter the Krebs cycle. 2) Lactate can be transported out of the fast twitch muscle fibers. It travels to adjacent slow twitch muscle fibers where it will be oxidized to produce energy.

title: Lactate and Muscle Function
content: At some point, everyone gets to the point where they cannot sustain the effort anymore. When there is a lot of MCT1 and mitochondrial function, lactate will increase and accumulate. But it’s not the lactate per se, but the hydrogen ions associated with the lactate that elicit acidosis of the micro environment of the muscle. An acidic environment will interfere with different functions in the muscle with regards to the force and velocity of the muscle fibers.

title: Fatigue and Lactate Oxidation
content: Fatigue may be caused by multiple factors. When lactate cannot be oxidized, it is exported to the blood. This is common in people with poor mitochondrial function, such as those with metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes, who cannot oxidize lactate during exercise. Their mitochondria in slow twitch muscle fibers don't use fat but rely on glucose. When they start using glucose, they produce lactate which they cannot oxidize, leading to its exportation to the blood.

title: Athletes and Glucose Oxidation
content: Well-trained athletes use more glucose and cannot achieve high power output without a massive amount of carbohydrate oxidation. Indirect calorimetry of recreational athletes or people with metabolic syndrome shows a maximum of 4 g/min carbohydrate oxidation. Elite athletes can get to 6.5 gram/ min, which is a massive amount of glucose oxidation. They also produce more lactate, but it doesn’t show up in the blood because it’s oxidized in the muscle. This correlates a lot with fat oxidation.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Exercise
content: The level of carbohydrate in the diet and ketogenic diets affects fuel utilization and power output during exercise. Metrics of cellular metabolism when on a ketogenic diet show a maximum fat oxidation of 1.3 g/min. This occurs almost immediately and is sustained until about 3.5 watts/kg; then it falls off and glucose becomes the dominant fuel source. At the end of the test, glucose oxidation was just under 6 g/min, about 24 KCAL/min.

title: Ketosis and Zone 2 Exercise
content: Metrics that define Zone 2 exercise should be adjusted for a ketogenic diet. The respiratory quotient (RQ; the ratio of VCO2 to VO2) depends on baseline carbohydrate intake. As you exercise, no matter what fuel you’re using, you keep increasing oxygen consumption. But if you don’t have much carbohydrates, you’re not going to produce much CO2. This will mislead the stoichiometric equation because the algorithm is going to think you’re using a lot of oxygen and now producing enough CO2. Instead, you’re going to be burning a lot of fat; that’s why you see fat oxidation north of 1 g/min.

title: Glycogen Content and Glucose Oxidation
content: They still saw 60% glycogen content in the muscle relative to what was there under high carb conditions. The capacity to oxidize 5.5-6 g glucose/min was still there; it just took a long time to get there.

title: Glutamine and Glycogen
content: Glutamine can be used as a fuel and to generate glucose. There is a 3rd element that is key in bioenergetics— glutamine. Glutaminase it’s highly expressed and utilized; it converts the amino acid glutamine to glutamate (which can enter the Krebs cycle).

title: ICU Patients and Metabolism
content: ICU patients use about 3x more glucose at rest than what we have. It’s part of the healing process. By the time someone gets into the ICU they use 3x the glucose at rest. An athlete uses the same amount of glucose during high intensity exercise but for a reduced amount of time 2-4 hours. For someone in the ICU, they are using that amount of glucose 24/7. Eventually the body is going to run out of glycogen in the muscle; this will cause huge stress to the body. Glutamine is another source of fuel. It directly enters the mitochondria and is oxidized. This is where cachexia come into play; every ICU patient becomes cachectic or suffers from muscle loss. This is the post ICU muscle wasting syndrome.

title: Hyperglycemia in ICU Patients
content: ICU patients also have hyperglycemia. In the acute ICU phase, they also have insulin resistance. Their hyperglycemia is off the charts. They are not going to get IVs of glucose. These patients benefit from receiving protein. Giving them glutamine has been shown to increase survival. The question becomes, “where is this hyperglycemia coming from when you do not have glycogen?” It is probably coming from protolysis (breakdown of protein) from muscles to release glutamine.

title: Exercise and Glucose Transporters
content: Once you exercise, you have insulin resistance and difficulty translocating GLUT4 transporters to the surface of the muscle. These move glucose into the cell. Skeletal muscle is probably the first tissue where diabetes starts because around 80% of the carbohydrates we have are oxidized in skeletal muscle. Pyruvate should be oxidized in the mitochondria. But with insulin resistance, GLUT4 transporters cannot be translocated.

title: Muscle Contraction and Glucose Uptake
content: Muscle contraction is an insulin-independent mechanism of translocating GLUT4 transporters to the cell surface. Glucose uptake also seems to be heavily dependent on fitness. The fittest athletes require virtually no insulin to translocate glucose into the muscle, through the insulin independent pathway. Insulin also translocates GLUT4 transporters to the cell surface; and these transporters start bringing glucose inside. This can be applied to people who have insulin resistance (with pre-type 2 diabetes)— exercise right after you eat that carbohydrate. This will bring those transporters to the cell surface to move glucose into the cell.

title: Lactate Testing and Blood Lactate Levels
content: Lactate testing can provide insights into how much a meal impacts blood lactate levels. Resting lactate level varies and is influenced by factors such as diet and exercise. A high carb meal can raise lactate levels. The lactate measured in the blood is heavily influenced by production and clearance.

title: Zone 2 Training and Fat Oxidation
content: In a patient or a world class athlete you have the ability to do indirect calorimetry and lactate testing to determine Zone 2 training. The gold standard would be to measure fat oxidation. With patients, a Zone 2 test can be based on their fat oxidation during an escalated VO2 max test.

title: Determining Training Zone
content: Exercising at a level where you can carry on a conversation and it feels a bit strained is a good surrogate for knowing you’re in Zone 2. You will be just at that threshold of not being able to carry on a conversation.

title: Using Heart Rate as a Guide
content: For people who have not done a metabolic test, heart rate is a good guide. First you need to determine your maximum heart rate (not the predicted maximum). For less trained people, this % is lower. Start at a broad range of 70-80% of their realized maximum heart rate, then make adjustments based on their rating of perceived exertion.

title: Resting Heart Rate and Fatigue
content: Your resting heart rate can indicate your level of fatigue. For example, if your normal heart rate is 50 and you wake up with a heart rate of 65, it could be a sign that you are fatigued. This ties into the concept of heart rate variability, as your heart rate will vary from day to day. Waking up with a higher heart rate is a red flag that you are fatigued. Some people’s heart rate is not super sensitive to this but elite athletes are for sure.

title: Heart Rate Variability and Exercise
content: If your Zone 2 heart rate is 130, some days it might be hard to get to that rate. You may be struggling at 110 beats per minute. This also falls into that concept of heart rate variability. Athletes will see this; they can’t get their heart rate up on days they are fatigued.

title: Medication and Heart Rate
content: Taking a large dose of a beta blocker can lower your heart rate, allowing you to push harder and generate a higher Zone 2. However, you have to be careful if you have low blood pressure. The medication lowers the heart rate but not the blood pressure.

title: Fatigue, Glycogen Stores, and Heart Rate
content: Fatigue and glycogen stores can affect your heart rate. When you don’t have enough glycogen storages, it’s very possible that adrenal activity is decreased. This results in a lower heart rate. When an athlete’s heart rate is not going up as it usually would, it could be a sign that they have less glycogen stores.

title: Brain Glucose Consumption
content: The brain uses about 100-125 g of glucose a day. When your work involves a lot of thinking and stress, the brain might need a lot more glucose. This can be supplied by gluconeogenesis. Muscles can also release glucose to be utilized by the brain as well.

title: Stress, Heart Rate, and Exercise
content: Stress can affect your heart rate and exercise performance. On days when you are stressed, your heart rate may not increase as it usually would during exercise. Taking a day off, sleeping more, and increasing carbohydrate intake can help improve performance the following day.

title: Importance of Resting Recovery
content: Resting recovery is key for performance. Overtraining can lead to fatigue and decreased performance.

title: Workload and Performance
content: When workload is too high, performance suffers. It may be necessary to cut back on training to make time for more sleep or relaxation.

title: Optimal Zone 2 Training
content: Optimal Zone 2 training involves a specific dose, frequency, duration, and type of exercise. High intensity training alone is not enough. Steady-state, sustained cardio (Zone 2) is also necessary. Important mitochondrial and metabolic adaptations can be achieved by exercising for one hour. The aim should be for 1 – 1.5 hour of exercise.

title: Frequency of Exercise
content: If you only train once a week, your mitochondrial function may deteriorate over time, especially as you age. Training 2 days a week might maintain what you have, but 3 days a week will start to show results. 4 days a week is ideal, and 5-6 days a week are even better, but not everyone has the time for this. 4-5 days a week of training is achievable for most people.

title: Starting an Exercise Program
content: For those just starting out, it's recommended to start with 20, 30, or 40 minutes of exercise and gradually build up to a 1 hour walk or run. If you bike, 1 hour 20 minutes or an hour and a half, 4 days a week is good. For patients just starting out, it's recommended to exercise 30 minutes, 3-4x a week.

title: Benefits of Zone 2 Training
content: For people who haven’t done much, even 20-30 minutes might start producing results. But eventually, the body will need longer training periods to boost mitochondrial function. The goal should be about an hour to an hour and a half.

title: Training Regimens
content: Comparing 4 training regimens, each totaling 4 hours per week: 4, 60-minute sessions; 1, 80-minute session and 3, shorter sessions; 2, 2-hour sessions; 1, 4-hours session. The best would be 4, 60-minutes sessions due to the higher frequency.

title: High Intensity Training and VO2 Max
content: High intensity training is important to improve glycolytic capacity. We lose glycolytic capacity as we age and it’s important to stimulate it. For VO2 max, high intensity training, a 4×4 protocol is recommended. This involves 4 minutes of the highest intensity, sustained exercise followed by 4 minutes of recovery. Repeat this 4-6x. Add a warm up and cool down on either end and this will be a little over an hour. Increasing the glycolytic system takes much less time, weeks or months. If you stimulate the glycolytic system 2-3 days you’ll see progress. Add a high intensity interval 2-3 days a week at the end of that Zone 2 training, and you’ll target both energy systems: the oxidative mitochondrial system and the glycolytic energy system.

title: VO2 Max and Longevity
content: From a lens of health, the data are unambiguous— VO2 max is highly correlated with longevity. There are not many variables that are more strongly correlated. But the levels don’t have to be that high. The VO2 max required here is 52-53 mL/min/kg.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Metabolic Health
content: Longevity is also highly related with mitochondrial function and metabolic health. There’s an aging process where we lose mitochondrial function, and there’s a sedentary component where we lose mitochondrial function. Increasing mitochondrial function takes months or years.

title: High Intensity Training and Diet Sustainability
content: High intensity exercise is not sustainable. Very extreme diets are not sustainable. If you combine both, it’s even worse.

title: Zone 5 Training Following Zone 2 Training
content: Is zone 5 training okay to do immediately following zone 2 training? It is okay to do Zone 5 training immediately after Zone 2 training, as it is done at the end, then exercise is over. But don’t do it in the reverse order because this will trigger all these hormonal responses and high blood lactate. We know lactate inhibits lipolysis. So if you have a high interval in the middle or the beginning and you don’t clear lactate very well, lactate interferes with the transport of fatty acids.

title: Zone 2 Exercise and Metabolic Health
content: The average might be Zone 2, but you’re oscillating between Zone 1, Zone 2, Zone 4, all the time. This routine helps to maintain metabolic health (1.5 hours of Zone 2 exercise ending with 5 minutes of high intensity effort, 4-5x a week).

title: Improvement in Metabolic Health with Age
content: Unbelievable improvement in people who just retired, in their 60’s, who now have time to exercise and sleep; they’re not overworked. People in their 70’s with the metabolic parameters of active 30-year olds. An 81-year old who is a world champion cyclist in the category of 80-85; he has metabolic parameters of someone in their 30’s.

title: Compounding Benefits of Exercise
content: The importance of compounding. Potential to make relatively quick changes in your glycolytic efficiency (to improve VO2 max). You could see 50% improvement in a few months. It’s day in and day out. Small compounded gains over years, and years, and years.

title: Effects of Metformin on Mitochondrial Function
content: Effect of metformin on mitochondrial function and blood lactate levels. Studies are ongoing to see if the impairment of mitochondrial function or elevated lactate levels seen in patients taking metformin is an artifact of the drug or is a real effect. Metformin seems to work for pre-diabetic patients and those with first-stage diabetes. Metformin inhibits complex I, which is key for mitochondrial function.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Aging
content: Mitochondrial impairment or dysfunction can be assessed with muscle biopsies. Metabolites at the cellular level and mitochondrial level are downregulated with aging. The question is why are these metabolites downregulated? Is the mitochondria per se downregulated with age? NAD is very important in glycolysis; it is needed to maintain redox status. NAD is utilized to convert glycerol-3-phosphate → 2,3-phosphoglycerate. When NAD is depleted the only thing that rescues it is lactate.

title: Supplements and Longevity
content: Supplements might improve mitochondrial function. Precursors to NAD are common (NR or NMN). If you boost NAD in the plasma, is it boosted in the cell? Is it beneficial to the mitochondria? Taking NAD may not increase longevity because longevity is not just one supplement or two or three or four or five. It’s a compendium on incredible amount of things that happen at the cellular level.

title: Supplements and Cancer Metabolism
content: There is a scenario where too much NAD could be harmful. In cancer patients, if you doubled their NAD levels, this could favor the tumor’s metabolism. Glycolysis is key in cancer cells and NAD is absolutely indispensable for that. A pilot study in mice showed a 15% increase in tumor growth in the NAD group.

title: Lactate, Exercise and Cancer
content: Lactate released from cells could feed a tumor. Lactate regulates genetic expression of the most important genes in breast cancer and lung cancer. Lactate is a mandatory byproduct of glycolysis. High glycolytic rate in cells will produce a lot of lactate. When lactate production is stopped, they see proliferation stop within hours. Exercise would increase your capacity for clearing lactate in the long term, but in the short term raises lactate. In a cancer patient specifically, the net impact of exercise is still a question.

title: Lactate and Gene Expression
content: The acute response to lactate is to increase the expression of 600+ genes. All these genes are involved in cellular homeostasis and in the benefits of exercise. Lactate is a stimulating molecule. In cancer the lactate keeps accumulating; exposure is chronic. Lactate is responsible for the acidic microenvironment of the tumor. The more acidic the tumor the more metastatic it is, the more aggressive, the more glycolytic.

title: Exercise and Cancer
content: Exercise might be beneficial for many patients. How does exercise affect exosomes released by cancer cells? Exosomes are microvesicles in the body that may be responsible for metastasis. One of the benefits of exercise is the crosstalk between skeletal muscle and many organs. Could this be mediated through exosomes released by muscles? Could exosomes released by muscle cells keep cancer at bay?

title: Exercise and Longevity
content: The deeper I go in the rabbit hole, into all things that relate to longevity, the more convinced I am that if you’re going to rank order things, there’s nothing that ranks above exercise, as the single most potent tool or agent we have to impact longevity. The chronic impact of exercise is undeniable geroprotective.

title: Metabolic Parameters in Long COVID Patients
content: A study of metabolic parameters of patients with long COVID was published. It was observed that mitochondria in long COVID patients (even in those who were previously healthy) look like those from people with type 2 diabetes in terms of fat oxidation and lactate production. People with long COVID struggle to breathe during simple tasks such as walking up stairs. A test of their pulmonary function looks normal. COVID affects cardiac muscles so their cardio function was measured; this too is normal. They undergo CPET testing, this is physiological, metabolic testing. They measure lactate as well.

title: Decline in Metabolic Health and Mitochondrial Function
content: Viruses can hijack the mitochondria for their own benefit, for reproduction— could COVID do the same thing? There are people with long COVID that improve in weeks or months; they go back to normal. But, there are a handful of people who after a year, have not improved one bit. Can exercise be used in a therapeutic way to stimulate mitochondrial function. Myocarditis occurs in some COVID infections; the rate is 2.3 cases of myocarditis per 100,000 people infected with COVID. Most cases of myocarditis are transient, they recover; but some are not. Myocarditis is inflammation of the cardiac muscle that results in depressed ejection fraction.

title: Long COVID and Mitochondrial Dysfunction
content: The study of long COVID patients indicates a global insult to the mitochondria in skeletal muscle, pointing towards mitochondrial dysfunction. This could be due to a microperfusion problem with the capillaries or microthrombosis preventing perfusion and resulting in increased lactate levels. Other viruses are known to hijack the mitochondria and disrupt it, but usually, this disruption subsides and mitochondrial function is restored after the symptoms are gone. The question remains why this virus is different. Most of these patients had a mild course of COVID and were not hospitalized. The study was done primarily on patients infected with the original variant and Delta.

title: VO2 Max and Exercise Prescription
content: There are limitations to using VO2 max as a metric for prescribing exercise. The relationship between Zone 2 as defined by maximum fat oxidation compared to VO2 max is not always predictable. Research studies with exercise have traditionally been based on VO2 max. However, athletes can improve tremendously at the cellular level but not at all at the cardiorespiratory level based on VO2 max. The VO2 max of an elite athlete does not come close to predicting performance. Instead of using VO2 max to look at longevity and fitness, a power test or a speed test on a treadmill can be used. Individuals who are not active and have poor fitness, have a lower VO2 max and a lower power output.

title: VO2 Max and Metabolic State
content: Exercise at a specific % VO2 max does not tell you anything about a person’s metabolic state. People with the same VO2 max might be in different metabolic states, oxidizing a lot more fat or carbohydrates. This means VO2 max does not correspond to the same metabolic status. A sedentary individual at 75% of their VO2 max might be around 3 mmol, whereas a world class athlete at 75% VO2 max, is about 1.5 mmol. So metabolically, they’re different but they are at the same VO2 max.

title: Athlete's Metabolism
content: An elite athlete oxidizes about 3 g/min. This is also different when they work at 50% VO2 max. Longitudinally carbohydrate oxidation and VO2 correspond very well. The same is true for fat oxidation. But if you look at the lactate levels of individuals in the same group, lactate and VO2 max don’t correlate. The correlation (R2) values are sometimes 0.2 or 0.1 or 0.3. If you want to be precise about prescribing exercise, use cellular surrogates such as lactate levels and fat oxidation is better than VO2 max. Using METs (metabolic equivalents of task) is prehistoric.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Aging
content: Declining mitochondrial function is a hallmark of aging. Zone 2 exercise is a way to measure mitochondrial function. Zone 2 exercise is both the treatment and the test. Now we know there is even more to look at on the cellular level.

title: Cellular Metabolism in Sedentary Individuals
content: Metabolomics reveals how cellular metabolism is altered in sedentary individuals. In sedentary individuals there is a decreased capacity of the mitochondria to oxidize fuels (pyruvate, fatty acids, and amino acids). There is also a significant decreases in the complexes that make up the electron transport chain. There is decreased capacity of the transporters that move different metabolites into the mitochondria. The transporter for pyruvate into the mitochondria is also dysregulated in sedentary individuals (as compared to active individuals). Similarly, oxidation of pyruvate in the mitochondria is dysregulated.

title: Implications of Sedentary Lifestyle
content: These people don’t have diabetes or prediabetes or clinical symptoms. But sedentary people are being used as the model to compare with unhealthy individuals. These sedentary individuals don’t have downregulation of GLUT4 transporters or abnormal glucose tolerance tests. As humans, we are meant to walk or exercise, so the sedentary individual needs an intervention.

title: Glucose Metabolism in Sedentary Individuals
content: Unpublished studies show a disruption in the mitochondrial pyruvate carrier (MPC) disrupts entry of pyruvate into the mitochondria. Most diabetes research has focused on the peripheral level. Looking at glucose levels, GLUT4 on the surface of the cell, insulin resistance, how much insulin the pancreas is releasing, etc. Dysregulation of glucose metabolism in sedentary individuals may occur 10-15 years ahead of clinical symptoms (such as insulin resistance).

title: Fatty Acid Metabolism in Sedentary Individuals
content: Studying the same thing with transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria. Measuring the levels of fat transporters (CPT1 and CPT2) in the mitochondria in sedentary individuals. These are also significantly downregulated. So in sedentary individuals, fatty acids will not be transported well into the mitochondria (where they can be oxidized). If fatty acids are injected into the mitochondria, they are not oxidized well either.

title: Cellular Changes in People with Diabetes and Metabolic Syndrome
content: People with diabetes/ metabolic syndrome have intramuscular triglycerides. These are fat droplets. This fat is not metabolically active, yet it continues to grow in size. Elite athletes also have intramuscular triglycerides but they are very active. 25-30% of the fat oxidation comes from that fat droplet.

title: Fat Droplets and Energy
content: This is probably a evolutionary mechanism to not rely on adipose tissue. Perhaps it is a quicker source of fatty acids for fuel. These fat droplets are constantly being turned over, oxidized and replenished.

title: Ceramides and Cardiovascular Disease
content: One thing they know is these fat droplets are very high in ceramides and diglycerides. Ceramides are key in the athelosclerotic process; they are a hallmark of cardiovascular disease. Historically it has been shown that ceramides are released from the liver. Now it is seen that ceramides are in intramuscular triglycerides.

title: Connection between Cardiovascular Disease and Type 2 Diabetes
content: These intramuscular fat droplets in people with type 2 diabetes keep growing and they release proinflammatory molecules. It is being worked on to establish the connections between type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease at the mitochondrial level. About 80% of people with type 2 diabetes also have cardiovascular disease (and vice versa), which is why it is called cardiometabolic disease.

title: Future Research
content: There’s going to be a lot more questions to be answered in the future when all of this data is published.
